"Weave o'er my brow, ye shades, your amplest gloom;</br>Deepen your murmurs at my feet, ye waves,</br>Precipitately plung'd; ye snow-crown'd hills</br>On whose high front the unstooping moon may rest</br>Her wearied car; and ye that wildly spread,</br>Vallies, your verdant bosom to the sun,</br>Rich with his genial ray, my druid step,</br>If due invok'd, receive; if now a strain</br>Loose from the check of art may hope to charm</br>Your mute attention, wave ye awful shades."

Such were the strains that from the pensive breast</br>Of old EUGENIO, smarting with the wrongs,</br>And sated with the vanities of life,</br>And now retreating from the haunts of men,</br>Not without rapture tho' unbidden flow'd.</br>Awhile he paus'd — and o'er the sylvan tracts</br>Of lonely Nature cast a long survey,</br>Silent, yet pleas'd:  upon his tranquil soul,</br>As on a mirror, the expansive scene,</br>Rich in variety and greatly fair,</br>New images imprest:  their native charm</br>Work'd on each sense, till his admiring thought</br>Burst from its silence.  Muse, record his thoughts!</br>And, if that grace be not denied thy claim,</br>In just simplicity's proportion'd phrase,</br>Not rude, not tasteless, not to passion weak,</br>Such as may win the approaches of the heart</br>Beyond the strutting pomp of giant words.

"For you, ye blue-ey'd Genii of the woods,</br>(Thus he renewed the ardor of his strain)</br>That wake the unfolding Spring, that bless from cold</br>The infant plants, and train the leafy scene</br>To full maturity of verdant life!</br>Naids, for you, and all in shells that haunt</br>The evening stream, to your romantic shrines</br>I now should bend, your votary; but the dream</br>Of classic days, and ye are of their train,</br>Are fled — then with me better may I bring,</br>Nor fabulous be they deem'd, nor obsolete,</br>Fit deities to guard my sylvan reign</br>And glad these solitudes.  What atheist heart</br>Shall scorn Integrity that knows no ill;</br>Courage that fears none; or the Briton power</br>Of Independence?  She was wont to bless</br>Our fathers' footsteps:  our effeminate age,</br>Effeminate and selfish, has exiled</br>Her liberal spirit from the palace roof.</br>To search for Freedom in these forest shades.</br>These are my household Gods.  Within their fane</br>Peace shall be priestless; in their leafy dells</br>Silence may sleep; along their secret paths</br>With calm security RETIREMENT rove,</br>Veiling her step.  Me too, ye holy choir,</br>Admit me to your train!  The turbid walks</br>Of man, in meditative mood, I leave;</br>Leave, yet resign not or to drear despair,</br>Or dumb oblivion, the sweet social love,</br>That linking thought to thought, and heart to heart,</br>In golden concord, gleams from soul to soul,</br>And sheds divinity on human breasts."

Again he paus'd — for stealing o'er his soul,</br>The sad remembrance of his former days</br>Hung, mist-like, on his thought.  One natural tear</br>He dropt, due tribute to the friends he lov'd,</br>The loves he lost, the venal friends that fled</br>His plaintive hours, when smit with penury—</br>But indignation on his cheek permits</br>No second tear:  collected, he resumes</br>The rigid tone of VIRTUE'S stoic lay.

"O ye loose Bacchants!  ye whose low delights</br>Disgrace your day; that share with wine and lust</br>The night; or, sunk in sloth, the social hours</br>Consume; ye, whose mir'd appetites obstruct</br>The light of reason, oh, approach not here!</br>Here Riot raves not — the lewd warbling lute</br>Stirs not the tingling blood — the sensual thought</br>Withers — the Passions wild and ill-inflam'd</br>Faint in the shades of solitude, and gasp</br>For the lost nourishment of absent vice.

"O ye, that softly thro' the mazy dance</br>Of fashion float, in silken luxury fair,</br>That sip, in vanity, the virgin bloom</br>Of beauty, tasteless to the enervate sense!</br>And ye, whose venal toil, from day to day,</br>Plods its unceasing round, who steal from night</br>The sleepless hour, Love's due, to gaze on gold,</br>Recede!  nor the sweet breath of solitude</br>Taint with disgust and fear, that freshly blows</br>To the pure sense.  The self-supported breast</br>Defying penury, and with Virtue's pride</br>Glancing contempt on wealth-puff'd insolence,</br>Or fairer yet, beyond an earthly ken</br>That daring looks, — Religion-lifted thought!</br>Suit these the relish of degenerate souls?

"Thou in majestic glory crown'd by Heaven,</br>Imperial Nature!  at thy woodland shrine</br>My votive verse receive; before thy throne,</br>In sweet vicissitude of service, stand</br>The New, the Beauteous, the Sublime: — fair forms</br>Shap'd to the Poet's eye!  thy vernal path</br>Thro' groves and gardens, or in wilder scenes,</br>Wilder, yet such as rural Pleasure loves,</br>Tenderly fair, May, blushing Grace!  Adorns:</br>She, gay attendant on thy roseate reign,</br>Breathes her ambrosial spirit in thy gales,</br>Greens ev'ry hill, relumes the languid sun,</br>And guides his doubtful luster to disclose</br>Thy woodbine foliage, peeping into bloom,</br>Fair bower of beauty!  kind retreat of love!</br>Lead on, bright nymph — enchanted in thy realms,</br>On the green summit of some mountain site,</br>High o'er the extremest verge, with lifted hands</br>And rapture-straining eye, in speechless joy,</br>Wild in sublimest grandeur, Wonder stands.</br>Playful beneath, o'er ev'ry May-blown flower</br>Varying the scented hue, from shade to shade</br>Chasing the sunny gleam, in tremulous dews</br>With diamond luster kindling purer grace,</br>Delighted Fancy roves, in fond pursuit</br>Of airy pastime; now, with bolder aim</br>Mingling the seasons, chills the Summer noon</br>With rush of sudden storm; now checks at will</br>The dark career of Winter, and o'erspreads</br>His sullen front with her all-cheering brow;</br>Then, as its shadowy splendor melt in air,</br>Catches its falling colours, and entwines</br>The bright illusive dyes, braiding for Hope</br>(Such the reward of ev'ry earthly aim)</br>A fairy wreath to crown his pilgrimage.

"Not all the scanty portions of delight</br>That Heav'n allots to man, with outstretch'd arm</br>AMBITION grasps; nor he who, falsely nam'd</br>Voluptuous, rifles ev'ry sickly charm</br>That Vice obtrudes upon his cheated sense;</br>She, as their moment of possession meets</br>His rising rapture, with insidious hand</br>Shifts their gay robes, and lo, his shudd'ring breast</br>Starts from the loath'd embraces of Disgust,</br>Or foul Remorse!  Sincerity of bliss</br>God meant not for the turbulent and vain.

"Deem ye the modest heart in shades retir'd,</br>Loose from the low contagion of the world,</br>Must pine in thought, or wearily benumb'd,</br>Count the dull hours, till flippant Folly comes,</br>Intrusive visitant!  from whose mien, uncheck'd</br>By sense, by Humour's festive hand unpush'd,</br>Leaps the loud laugh!  an independent joy,</br>That leans not on the languid form of things,</br>By art's deceptive pencil colour'd gay,</br>Blesses the ingenuous mind; a virtuous joy,</br>That, while it charms, corrupts not.  Such the sense</br>Harmonious of consenting truths; fair ease;</br>Fair exercise of mind; domestic peace;</br>Disdain of slavery; Reason's temperate rule;</br>Contempt of folly; conscious worth; and Faith</br>That dares with eagle eye the thrones of Heaven.

"Who on his soul that feels this angel train</br>Of bliss descend, tho' rudely from his thatch</br>Cold ice-drops hang, would spurn from silent life</br>Her fair-ey'd joys!  or, with the fretful spleen,</br>Groan at the oppression of a tranquil day?

"Who by fear'd habit to each kinder sense</br>Not grossly dull, nor hopeless to obtain,</br>Who for his soul but meditates to woo,</br>Tho' in some distant hour that never comes,</br>These heavenly ministers of human joy?

"Him that neglectful of their love, in thought</br>Untasted yet, his idle fancy bathes</br>In masques, and pageant pomps, and reveling courts,</br>Or, with lewd Comus dancing, thirsts to drink</br>Circaean pleasures, from the charmed cup,</br>Him, hapless youth! — ah, save him e'er he fall!</br>Error shall lead or Guilt usurping rule.

"Save him!  ere dissipating rage exhaust,</br>Or from his bloom the rust of lucre eat</br>The core of joy; ere, pale in palsied age,</br>Wealthy too late, not wise, from virtuous bliss</br>Too long estrang'd, without an offering laid</br>On the fair altars of domestic peace,</br>To Vanity's delusive shrine he bow.

"The voice of Wealth shall never woo unheard</br>Her selfish aid:  with quick regard she comes,</br>Gloats on the sculptur'd roof, the gorgeous plate</br>Dazzling the eye; and rich illumin'd strokes</br>Of TITIAN'S breathing art; in gay alcove</br>Proudly reclines, and kindles at the smile</br>Of marble Loves and leaden painted Gods.</br>To those (while obelisks and streaming vanes</br>Emulous of fame, aspiring from the shades</br>Slop'd to admit his view, the Traveller's haste</br>With envious wonder check) she, proud in thought,</br>Kind in pretext, to Flattery's echoing eye</br>With curious finger points, lest unobserv'd,</br>Uprais'd, a ray of grandeur fall in vain.</br>Lo, all her aid and boast — tho' trimly wreathed</br>By polish'd art, tho' gemm'd, supplies the crutch</br>Youth's steely nerves to age?  or can the shroud,</br>Fring'd with a golden hem, pride mixed with woe,</br>And foppery with corruption, charm the dead?

"Pensively fair, within her hazle shades,</br>At noon, when all the liberal airs of Heaven,</br>Fresh'ning the valley's violet sweetness, fall</br>In faint subjection to the eager heat,</br>RETIRMENT musing sits:  Pleas'd by her side,</br>Smoothing her bosom softness, Peace extends</br>A breathless calm of soul; the distant din</br>Of tumult scares not her divine repose;</br>Anger is silent; from the hallow'd scene</br>Envy, the bosom hell, to selfish breasts,</br>Hissing, retreats; Fear to the ambush flies</br>Of secret guilt; and sad unsated Care</br>Feeds on the vitals of mean drudging Vice.</br>Mute is the hour — the inward light of thought,</br>By passion'd blasts unruffled, clearly hangs</br>Its life-discerning lamp; the mental world</br>Unfolding gleams; the imagery of soul</br>A genuine shape and due complexion wears</br>Chastened beneath its beam; hence sacred Truth</br>And Virtue hence their deathless orbs illume.</br>Let Avarice, mounted on his yellow heaps,</br>Fretting his anxious eye with sleepless dread</br>Of fraud or theft, her dark enjoyments claim</br>Unenvied and unpitied; let Conceit,</br>In proudest folly, at her mimic glass,</br>Elaborately sleek her scented locks,</br>And deeply studious of attractive airs,</br>Creating charms and curtseying at the view,</br>Worship her shadow; and let loose-rob'd Lust,</br>Sighing or smiling, as it seems her best,</br>In all o'erstepping Nature and the grace</br>Of modest Love, with lure of artful looks</br>Urge her dishonest aims, and to her breast</br>Constrain tir'd Pleasure panting; shall thy soul,</br>O meditate a moment, shall thy soul,</br>Breathing immortal hopes and wrought in Heaven,</br>Her sacred ardor check, in sensual mire</br>Wallowing with shame?  the God within thy mind</br>Shrinks in the dregs of earth, and dead to Fame.

"Envy not thou in honourable shades</br>Bosom'd, and virtuous peace, the laurel leaf</br>That veils the sternness of the warrior's brow,</br>While o'er the desolation of mankind</br>Nature and Pity mourn.  Thou hast thy aims,</br>Of grandeur, thou thy glory; thou canst boast,</br>While Nature and applauding Virtue smile,</br>Conquest o'er life:  the appetites enchained</br>Bow to thy will; and not a struggling wish</br>O'erleaps the limits of thy modest leave;</br>Here is thy pride, thy bliss; the ills of fate</br>Soften'd recede; the spirit of thy mind,</br>Genius of noblest thoughts, elate and fair,</br>In virtuous freedom breathes; the equal love</br>Of Heaven she claims; and conscious of her right</br>Bends not to man her sphere-aspiring worth.</br>Just to thyself, at the commanding voice</br>Of lacker'd Wealth, degrade not thou thy soul</br>Awfully shivering!  nor in supple haste</br>Trip at the beck of Pride, to catch the smile</br>That low'ringly descends!  To others just,</br>Thou never, the fair fence of order torn,</br>With rudest obloquy and cynic pride</br>Bark, envious, at the footsteps of the great."

Here, while his bosom panted with disdain</br>Of the base arts that sadden life with woe,</br>And the dark services that worthless men</br>Administer to wealth, again he paus'd,</br>And for a third time check'd his glowing strain;</br>Not long he check'd — Not yet the roseate morn</br>Resign'd its dewy luster to the noon,</br>While his free footsteps rang'd along the glades,</br>Or climb'd each airy peak of steep access.</br>Warm with the love of nature and of truth,</br>Again he sung:  the tenor of his lay,</br>Still in a plaintive, yet indignant air,</br>Rebuk'd the vices, mourn'd the woes of Life:</br>To vales and rocks his solitary song</br>He pour'd, nor human audience wish'd nor fear'd;</br>While thus, in prelude soft, and milder tone,</br>He hail'd the sylvan Goddess of his choice.

"Awake, ye western airs, with rosy breath</br>Favoring the youthful year, awake!  invite</br>(Pleas'd with the kindly task) her devious step!</br>Ye airs of Heaven, awake!  and on her bloom</br>Of soul your life-inspiring spirit shed!</br>Broke by your whispers her ambrosial rest,</br>She quits her mossy couch; to woo the smile</br>Of Nature, bright'ning ev'ry rural charm,</br>Retirement comes:  still at the lov'd return</br>Of eve and morn, day's orient path and fall</br>Bright-purpled, the divine recluse shall come.</br>Wreath'd from the mountain's side, in billowy way,</br>Ye mists recede!  nor to the forest skirts</br>Darkly adhere!  or linger o'er the edge</br>Of reedy stream!  smit with their vernal charms,</br>Thro' their wild sweetness, her enchanted step</br>Retirement leads; and winding thro' the maze</br>Of sun, and shade, of wood and hilly heights,</br>With unremitted love, in mind pursues</br>The silent track of nature-breathing thought.

"Mean while the beauteous-handed Spring unfolds</br>The azure grace of Heaven; and earth beneath,</br>Loosening her veins to joy, looks up and smiles.</br>Retirement in her walk, enraptur'd, marks</br>The bounty-blessing scene.  The tender bloom,</br>Wak'd from its annual death, salutes her eye,</br>Waving in triumph to the passing air</br>Its thousand colours; even the lowly herb</br>Wreaths its impatient head, of richer life</br>Ambitious, proudly struggling from the earth.</br>The air breathes music; and the chearful voice</br>Of melody, untutor'd, unconfin'd,</br>From field to fountain wings its warb'ling course,</br>The solace of the groves:  the wond'ring herds</br>Pause from their food, and frisk in wanton joy.</br>Thus while all nature kindles into soul,</br>Impelling vigour thro' the enliven'd veins</br>Of herb or beast, the animating force</br>Thrills to the heart of man:  spontaneous bliss,</br>Borne on the tide of spirits, gushes forth</br>'Gainst every sense wild-dashing; eye and ear</br>Quicken anew with rapture; joy and hope,</br>Beam'd or re-echo'd from each vernal scene,</br>And gratitude and love inspire the heart.
"In every gale, with genial pleasure rich,</br>Poetic Virtue breathes, and, free of power,</br>Noble in object, from the well-ton'd soul</br>With generous impulse strikes the harmonious thought.

"Yet ere thy hand, with daring spirit warm,</br>Awake the wires of Fancy, ere she draw</br>Her roseate veil and smile thee to her love,</br>Mark, where, with scowling aspect, Dullness stands:</br>Wearily slow his words — drowsy their tone—</br>Muttering with solemn air and sapient pride</br>Proverbial documents and grandam lore,</br>He shakes the affected pity of his brow,</br>In meanest triumph, o'er the withering fate</br>Of Genius, and the proud neglect of worth.

"Lo, he who died of hunger and of thirst—</br>He, who on Mulla's banks, in fairy pomp,</br>Marshall'd his splendid chivalry, and deck'd</br>With virtue-breathing shews ELIZA'S court.</br>The trump re-echoes; and the redcross Knight</br>Issues in ardor forth; adventurous deeds</br>Urging thro' danger to the steeps of fame;</br>The lady of his love, herself the meed</br>Of his high triumph, animates his heart.</br>Scar'd at his sun-bright shield and haughty lance</br>Pointed with death, the chariot's winged speed</br>Falters — unshelter'd from his fury, falls</br>The faithless Soldan; the dark wizard shrieks;</br>The ghostly chambers, the wild shadowy hosts,</br>And magic murmurs melt in angry air.</br>Rapt by his powerful strain, the elated soul</br>Spurns the dull features of existent time,</br>And its dark grain of manners:  charm'd in thought</br>To meet his fairy imagery of song,</br>She in the fable of heroic days</br>Longs to have mix'd her flame.  Sublime or sweet,</br>The trumpet thunders, or the plaintive lute</br>Its tenderest accent breathes; in plain or court,</br>(While the bard died of hunger and of thirst,)</br>Wood nymphs and regal dames ador'd his songs.
"See 'fall'n on evils days and evil tongues,</br>Rolling in vain his perish'd orbs of sight,</br>In Freedom's aid o'erply'd,' the bard of Heaven</br>Best favour'd! — such the crown of human worth!

"O ye white bosoms, true to Nature, turn,</br>Like the bright flower before the orb of day,</br>To every movement of the Poet's mind!</br>Blest be the graceful weakness that descends</br>In silent tears, that heaves your pitying hearts,</br>When wrung with deep and delicate distress</br>Monimia mourns; or she who kneels in vain</br>For the lost blessing of a father's love,</br>For the dear forfeit of a husband's life,</br>Poor hapless Belvidera!</br>Still as your souls in rapt attention hush'd,</br>Sigh o'er their fate, let Indignation point,</br>Virgins and Youths!  and all whose bosoms bleed</br>At storied grief and fabulous despair!</br>Where the Creator of those passion'd scenes</br>Naked, unsheltered, hunger-smit and poor,</br>Poor to the last extremity of woe,</br>Sadly beseeches, ere he sinks in death,</br>The scantiest boon that ever Genius ask'd,</br>That e'er the meanest nature can implore,</br>One morsel from your board — it comes too late—</br>And the Muse hymns her OTWAY'S soul to Heaven.

"But who is he whom later garlands grace?</br>Lo, his worn youth beneath the chilly grasp</br>Of penury faints; and in her mournful shroud</br>Dark'ning all joy, all promises of good,</br>All health, all hope, sad Melancholy saps</br>In drear decay the fabric of his mind:</br>See shuddering Pity o'er his fallen soul</br>Wrings her pale hands!  Regardless of the guide</br>That lifts his step, regardless of the friend</br>That mourns, nor sadly conscious of himself,</br>Silent yet wild, his languid spirit lies:</br>The light of thought has wandered from his eye,</br>It glares — but sees not.  Yet this breathing corse,</br>This youthful driveller, Nature's ghastliest form,</br>(Oh, who would love the lyre?) in all the courts</br>Of Fancy, where abstracted Beauty play'd</br>With wildest elegance, his ardent shell</br>Enamour'd struck, and charm'd her various soul.

"See, later yet, and yet in drearier state,</br>Where dawning Genius struggling into day</br>Sinks in a dark eclipse; no friendly heart</br>With love auspicious, and no angel-hand</br>With prosperous spell his labouring sun relieve,</br>And chace the gather'd clouds that drop with blood.

"Such were the lights of soul that in the Heaven</br>Of Fancy blaz'd:  the energic breath of thought,</br>Fanning their transports, vivify'd their sphere</br>With mental beauty; and their sacred songs</br>Shall stream in luster o'er each falling age,</br>When fainter records die:  mean while the mind,</br>Mourning their fate, not emulous of their worth,</br>To other annals turns:  the historic page,</br>Breathing with life, before her eye unfolds</br>The varying garb of Manners, and reveals</br>The soul of Nature.  Shapes of ancient Time,</br>Glitter before her view:  with Virtue, Faith,</br>With Freedom, Fame descends.  The alter'd scene</br>Discolours now — now darkens:  Fraud to Faith</br>Is link'd; to Freedom, Death:  the tribes of art,</br>And the wild passions, from the intent of God</br>Corrupted by the vicious skill of man,</br>Hark or impetuous, madden o'er the maze</br>Of Life:  from these the unambitious mind</br>Escap'd, securely frames in humbler vales</br>Her nest, and makes Content her Fame.  Less pleas'd,</br>Less ardent her uncheated eye pursues</br>The vast emprize of Valour, when the Pomp</br>Of Heroism, in imperial folly, stalks</br>Proud with a golden pall; even then recur</br>To Pity's tender thought, the wounds of Love,</br>The devastation, and the bloody track</br>The ambitious sword has wrought.  The widow's tear,</br>The cradled wretch that reckless of the cause</br>Wails to his mother's weeping, the poor Sire</br>Spoil'd of his aged boast, ah, Sire no more!</br>With her o'erwhelm the long applauding shout</br>And rattling wheel of Triumph.  Still the Mind,</br>In weak excursion, o'er the troubled scene</br>Fearfully hovers; but with cow'ring wing,</br>Hopeful of rest, when on some brittle joy</br>Well pleas'd she stoops, beneath her step it breaks.

"See in the treacherous bowl the bliss of love</br>And light of life descend:  the friendly breast</br>Falls by the hand it sav'd:  for patriot worth</br>The tyrant grinds his ax:  religious zeal</br>Waves forth the torch of hell, and Horror flames</br>Woe and amazement o'er the souls of men.

"From private sorrow rising, Pain and Death</br>Expand their powers; a nation gleams in war;</br>The tumult thickens; the unfeeling sword</br>Grides thro' the kindred breast.  See Rout and Shame</br>Speed o'er the corse-throng'd way!  See gory shapes</br>And armed Terrors rush!  in mockery see</br>O'er regal Sorrow sit in stern array</br>The Traitorous Judgment!  in the eye of Heaven,</br>O'er his meek brow dishonourable Death</br>Unwinds his sable flag:  O sad display</br>Of Virtue garb'd in Misery's bloodiest veil!

"Shew me the turret on which Pride may place</br>Her grateful ambition?  where the bliss</br>That mocks not the embracing hope?  the Life,</br>That fluttering thro' the busy-dreaming world</br>Wings to the house of rest that dreadless course</br>Which silent worth would wish?  A Nation's love</br>By patriot deeds and death defying fame</br>Let Valour win; let rival Beauty vaunt</br>O'er the defeated glories of that cheek</br>Beneath the living luster of whose beams</br>Her envy paled; then gaily let them come,</br>Pride in their eye and pleasure at their heart,</br>And mark where GLORIANA lies — Behold!</br>On the cold pavement for the jewell'd throne,</br>Sad choice!  of human vanity and grief</br>Most feelingly expressive, low she lies.

"Mark, as the soothing friend, or to her ear</br>In wily humour creeping, the base speech</br>Of adulation breathes 'Dread Sovereign Queen,</br>Imperial Mistress, Arbitress of Earth!'</br>Mark if the Goddess at the alluring sound</br>Unveil her sorrowing eye; Mark if the pride</br>Of Empire, glistning with on her crown, adorn</br>Her brows with horror; if a nation's prayer</br>Gladden her heart; stern at her bosom hang,</br>Bathed in her blood, and twisted with the strings</br>Of life, the inexorable fiends of woe.</br>On the cold pavement still she lies; Dismay,</br>Jealous Remorse, and Pain, and secret Guilt,</br>Wearying her blasted moments, till her age,</br>Pity her aged grief!  ebbing, dissolves</br>In all the sobbing impotence of tears,</br>Quiv'ring with speechless agony that mocks</br>Relief and Hope, invoking Death in vain.

"Well may the hind, in penury grown old,</br>Thro' whose sole casement  the dim light of morn</br>A scanty ray intrudes, his shatter'd nerves</br>Rousing to toil, with pitying visage ask,</br>Was this a Queen?  could this weak withering wretch,</br>This fool of angry Nature, gird her brow</br>With glory?  and a female soul exalt,</br>At which the knee of kingdoms sued to bend?

"Such is the fate of Man — the boast of Heaven</br>And wonder of the Gods — from scene to scene</br>Teazing his anxious thought in idle chace</br>Of Folly's painted shadows.  Love a while</br>Toys with his burning Youth; then Wealth, then Fame,</br>A sickly lustre shedding o'er his age,</br>Becken  his eager step:  behind, unseen,</br>Sabling the splendid tints of Fancy, comes</br>Disgust:  Disgust or Disappointment crowns</br>With numb'd satiety, or anguish'd ache,</br>In every scene the chace — the dupe of Hope,</br>The slave of Sorrow — scourg'd by angry Fate</br>In sever'd agitation to the Grave.

"Now while in threat'ning horror onward move,</br>Dark'ning the vale of life, — ah nearer now!</br>The blood-stain'd clouds — Thundering in wrath, while now</br>Deepens the storm, from Folly's baby crown</br>Beating the gilt, and to the heart of Vice,</br>(Tho' clos'd his eyes in superstitious gloom)</br>Flashing dismay, the Moral Thought may walk</br>Calm and secure amidst the war of woes;</br>From ill educing good, while life unveils</br>Her splendid miseries.  Let the fraudful brow</br>Of Care, the lying smile of Love, and all</br>The ghastly images of Guilt, impress</br>This one great lesson on thy heedful soul,</br>(Parent of noblest deed, of power to quench</br>The fears, and pains, and all the death of Life)</br>Humbly to hope, from Virtue's crowning hand,</br>Bliss in a future age, a fairer world,</br>Meanwhile to mark the living mind with worth,</br>The sweet security of lowly life,</br>To love, and silent Grandeur of Content."

Here from the murmurs of his solemn strain</br>EUGENIO ceas'd — and sighing — and in his mind</br>Silent revolv'd the numerous ills of fate—</br>Not yet the Noon had with its radiant beam</br>Emblaz'd the deep, when bounding o'er the wave</br>Full in his sight, for on a cliff he sat</br>That fronted the broad main, a gallant ship</br>Clos'd its wide wings, and anchor'd on the shore.</br>Who shall describe his transport?  May he trust</br>His flatter'd sight?  He may.  The wealthy freight,</br>The gallant crew, long deem'd in ocean sunk,</br>Present their treasures at their owner's feet;</br>That owner is EUGENIO.  Now his heart</br>(Such is the heart of inconsistent man)</br>Flush'd with the glare of his returning wealth,</br>Already to his solitary joys</br>Sings an eternal requiem.  Now, farewell</br>Thou russet vest, and thou contracted cot,</br>Within whose sordid cincture and dull bourne</br>Misanthropy retiring, may obscure</br>Her canker'd hatred; or some Hermit veil</br>His holy apathy and deaden'd soul.</br>Farewel for ever to the torpid reign</br>Of Silence; her best joys and fairest scenes</br>The soul exhausting soon, to social bliss</br>Returns with unextinguishable love.</br>Not yet the Night had with her ebon shade</br>Curtain'd the earth, when his impatient step</br>Sought the gay Town; and his ambitious heart,</br>With all the eagerness of untried Youth,</br>And careless of lost loves and venal friends,</br>Yet once more with the gay and busy world</br>Plung'd in the waves of Passion and of Care.</br>
